isis.stitle: REPAIR INSTRUCTIONS FOR FIBERGLASS AND PLASTIC (ABS) MATERIAL - PLASTIC (ABS) - REPAIR PROCEDURE

item.para: Major damage (holes with loose or missing pieces)
Structural damage (to the mounting system or to accessory attachment surface)

step1.para: Remove all parts and accessories interfering with the area to be repaired. Clean the repair area with Sikkens No. M600 Wax and Grease Remover, or equivalent, to remove all surface residue, then wipe dry.
Grind and sand the area prior to repair if necessary. Care must taken to keep the grinder or sander in constant motion to prevent heat build up. Blow the area clean.

warning.para: FIBERGLASS ABS PLASTIC REPAIRS - To avoid breathing dust and fumes, wear approved protective equipment. Breathing fiberglass ABS plastic dust and/or fumes can be hazardous to your health.

1. OSHA standards should be consulted with respect to mandatory requirements as well as suggested procedures to minimize exposure. (Reference: Title 29, Code of Federal Regulations, Section 1910, 1001.)
2. Whenever possible work on fiberglass and ABS plastics in a separate area away from other operations.
3. Always wear a respirator approved by NIOSH or MSHA during all fiberglass or ABS plastic repairs.
4. Worker clean-up. Wash your hands before eating, drinking or smoking.

step1.para: Clean the area with Sikkens No. M600 surface cleaner, or equivalent.
Scuff the damaged area with a Scotch Brite No. 7447 Red Pad, then clean the area.
Paint with Sikkens Autocryl Filler, Autocryl Color and Matting Clear.
Drill a small hole at each end of the crack to stop crack extension.
Form a V-groove the length of the damage using a burr bit on a drill or equivalent ( Figure 59). The sides of the "V" should be tapered no more than 45 degrees.

figure.caption: Figure 59. Form V-Groove the Length of Damage

note.para: Care should be taken when grooving the damaged area. The bumper end caps and the side skirts are .125 inch thick. Small cracks or gouges can become major repairs. This is because large cracks will result when too much material is removed during the repair.

step1.para: Scuff the area about 1/2 inch (13 mm) larger than the damaged area with Scotch Brite No. 7447 Red Pad.
The damaged area is then filled with hot melt adhesive, epoxy adhesive/filler, or sealed using the hot welding technique.
After drying and cooling, the patched area is sanded to match the surrounding area and is ready for finish.

svcsubproc.title: Major Repairs (Holes With Loose or Missing Pieces)

step1.para: Cut out the damaged area. If the damage is only on the outside wall of a double walled panel, cut a hole large enough in the rear wall to allow a patch one inch (25 mm) larger than the surface hole to pass through.

Apply the surface patch to the inside of the outer wall with epoxy adhesive. Apply a patch to the outside of the inner wall using the same technique. Make sure each patch is overlapping the edge of the hole by approximately 1/2 inch (13 mm) all around.
Fill the outer patched surface with epoxy adhesive/filler, then sand with coarse (No. 40) grit sand paper to match the surrounding contour.
Finish sand and feather edge with No. 220/360 grit sand paper. The area is now ready for finishing.
Prepare and patch the damaged area the same as Major Repairs.

note.para: Components such as bracket mounts, etc. can be fabricated from sheet stock using standard shop tools, a heat gun and adhesives ( Figure 60).

figure.caption: Figure 60. Bracket Mounts, Etc. Can Be Fabricated From Sheet Stock

step1.para: Use epoxy adhesive/filler to attach the components. Reinforcements will be important in these situations because of stress and vibration experienced in these areas.
